comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
Hurraah, Hurrah Limerick features on NLI in Flickr but where's this Georges Street I ask.  That beautiful thoroughfare is O'Connell St with The Crescent and O'Connell Avenue in the distance.
Limerick is of course a very old city but in the 1700's/1800's a planned city on a grid was developed and this street was part of what is/was Newtown-Pery.  The massed ranks are marching in the opposite direction to modern parades as we normally had parades that marched down towards the O'Connell Street/William St. junction behind the photographer. 

I know they look like policemen but I can't see that many "polis" having a role in Limerick around that time.  They are marching in the direction of the "New" barracks, now Sarsfields Barracks, and I suspect that this might explain the direction and the echelons.

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: there seem to be a band marching in the opposite direction???

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tj_q8] No TJ, if you look closely in Original size you will see that they have the bayonet frogs to the left just like the group closest the camera.  I was just going to comment on the bayonets, they are each wearing a bayonet in a frog on a white belt.  This is more a military item of kit than police and looking at the dress of the NCO's they are wearing sashes etc which is once again more a military affectation than a police one.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
But wouldn't it have been George St in 1900? The 1901 Census has Louis Sommerfield, tailor, a widower with 4 children, born in Germany. His death was announced in the Limerick Chronicle in 1909, and it described him as a "highly-esteemed citizen" and "a gentleman of a very courteous and kindly disposition". He had a nasty shock in 1901 (Limerick Chronicle 8th June):
A startlingly sudden death occurred this afternoon in the city. Mr. Augustus Switzer, book-keeper in the employment of Mr louis Sommerfield, military tailor, George street, after having filled up a cheque, was seen by Mr. Sommerfield to lean over on the book, and almost without a word, died in a minute or two. Mr Switzer was elderly and unmarried. he had not complained of being ill, and his sudden death will come as a shock to all who knew him. The police have been communicated with, and an inquest will be held.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] John Spooner is right it was of course Georges street back then.  I may be wrong (again:-(() but why would you have such a significant mass of police in Limerick at that time?  It did not have a training depot and none of the police establishments in the city would have been large enough to accomodate them for any time.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] No offence to the police and their marching Swordscookie, in fact I usually reserve the "Soft Shoe Shuffle' remark for Jolly Jack Tar.
My own efforts at marching when I was drafted for a spell in the Portsmouth Barrack Guard left a lot to be desired.  I could never get my rifle to assume the correct 'angle of the dangle' and one occassion while marching under trees my rifle was snatched right out of my hands and after we had marched the plattoon passed the trees there was mine, still there and dangling forlornly from a tree where I had got the old Lee Enfiel .303 forsight securely caught in a branch.
When I tried to explain to the the G.I. (Gunnery Instructor)  that I couldn't help being born with streamlined shoulders he took that as just plain 'Dumb Insolence'  and acted accordingly.
Dotted around the old RNB Barracks huge parade ground were every twenty yards a planted tree.
I was sent running around that parade ground so many times as a punishment  I swear I began to think that I was in a forest!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] Would pay good cash money to see that gun dangling from the tree, and the look on your Gunnery Instructor's face when you tried to explain about your "streamlined shoulders"! Is that a recognised disability in the armed forces?  :D
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Certainly not NLI, it was just the first excuse that came to mind and was recognised as such by the very experienced Instructor.  From that point on he would of course see it as his bounden duty to 'smarten me up' and teach me when to keep my smart ass comments to myself! 
Stap me, I never did learn that particular lesson !

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Next to the young fella with his hands on his head in this you will see a cart with two milk churns on board.  In that era and right up to the late 50's milk was sold "loose" out of churns like that in the backs of cars/vans and off carts.  The driver had his measures, 1/4, 1/2 and pint size and when you bought some he always gave a "tilly" or extra drop for luck!  Ah! God be with the old days:-)  I'm surprised not to see a coal cart delivering coal.  There was a famous Limerick character known as "Cut the Bags" who used cut the bags so that he could sell you a 'full' bag of coal that was below measure.  A really cunning person would be described as being as cute as cut the bags!  This adds nothing to our knowledge of the photo but I'm getting all sentimental about my native place!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] points out that is the Shannon St junction to the right leading down from Roches St on the left and down onto Henry St. and the quays. Just past that junction was the Royal George Hotel and I never realised where the name came from (doh!)  Further up was a tea merchants and up until the 80's the statue of a chinese man in oriental garb was outside the shop over the window.  I think you can just see it past the next junction.  Interestingly a lot of the property in that street is now owned by a Chinese gentleman who has several restaurants in the city and elsewhere.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Ulster Bank was in #115 by 1912! You can just make it out at left here: Could be this Ulster Bank, from 1904 in the DIA. Looking at Ulster Banks history, they were only opening their first branches in Cork, Limerick etc at this time, so i think it is safe to say that 115 became a bank in 1904, and this photo pre-dates that. I can't find any info online on when electric lighting was installed in O'Connell/George Street.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: This could be the Munster Fusiliers. Either before or after Boer War deployment. Certainly the "Zulu" helmets are in evidence in contemporary front-line uniforms. Though not sure about dress/parade uniforms. I suspect however that we're looking at the RIC on parade here. The RIC were organised on military lines, so it wouldn't be unusual to see this kind of drilling discipline. Also, the military tunics and woodentop helmets were the standard. (See this BoardsDotIE thread for comparative images). In terms of the numbers, the RIC had seven barracks in the city. And more still on the outskirts. In the lead-up to the civil war, there were upwards of 300 RIC men in Limerick. So the volume of marchers doesn't preclude it being an RIC "outing" either. (See this overview.) Would be good to get a press reference to the march/parade to confirm definitively.

comment.author: 42126491@N06
comment._content: According to the Jim Kemmy Municipal Museum it was the Royal Irish Constabulary marching in that picture. Alas no date given. museum.limerick.ie/index.php/Detail/Object/Show/object_id...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Definitely not Royal Irish Constabulary. Although the constabulary's uniform was based on the British riflemans, their badges and equipment were blackened. The helmets are 1878 pattern and in this case the spike on top of the helmet has a ball on the end instead of a sharp point which indicates these are Royal Artillery troops. The helmets were issued in 1878 with the spike, the Royal Artillery added the ball on the end in 1881 to avoid impaling their horses when attaching harnesses. The uniform of the Royal Artillery was dark blue in colour by the way. A nice view of a Royal Artillery officer with the 1878 pattern artillery helmet

comment.author: 42126491@N06
comment._content: That's a great observation about their helmets (ball-pointed top). The city had also an Artillery Barracks on Mulgrave Street. Here is a link to a picture of the 9th Field Battery Royal Artillery Limerick 1898. Although the quality is poor, however they seem to be wearing a differnt type of hat.

comment.author: 42126491@N06
comment._content: Here is a Unit Listing of the Crown Forces who served at the New Barracks 1890-1900. Was this type of uniform worn by any of them below? 1900 – 1st Battalion, King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry 1900 - 17th Cancers 1899 – 2nd Battalion, The Cheshire Regiment 1899 - 17th Cancers 1898 – 2nd Battalion, The Cheshire Regiment 1898 – 1st Battalion, The Royal Irish Regiment 1898 - 17th Cancers 1897 – 1st Battalion, The Royal Irish Regiment 1897 – 8th Royal Irish Hussars 1896 – 1st Battalion, The Royal Irish Regiment 1896 – 14th Hussars 1895 – 1st Battalion, The Royal Irish Regiment 1895 – 1st Battalion, The Manchester Regiment 1894 – 1st Battalion, The Royal Irish Regiment 1894 – 1st Battalion, The Manchester Regiment 1894 - 14th Hussars and 15th Hussars 1893 – 1st Battalion, The Manchester Regiment 1893 - 10th Hussars 1892 - 2nd Battalion, The Black Watch (Royal Highland Regiment) 1891 - 2nd Battalion, The Black Watch (Royal Highland Regiment) 1891 - 15th Kings Hussars 1891 – 2nd Battalion, Worcestershire Regiment 1890 – 2nd Battalion, Worcestershire Regiment Source from book “Images of Sarsfield Barracks”.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Interesting photo of the RFA at Mulgrave street KölnMike, the hat that the soldiers are wearing is the field service cap which was introduced as a replacement for the pillbox hat around the turn of the century. I doubt very much if any of the regiments above would have worn the helmet without the sharp spike on top, as far as I am aware the ball on the end was unique to the Royal Field Artillery, the Royal Garrison Artillery and the various artillery militias. Infantry regiments would have worn a helmet very much like this one Lincolnshire Regiment officer's 1878 Pattern home service helmet

comment.author: 66941036@N05
comment._content: The Army Service Corps also wore a ball topped helmet and provided drivers for 'artillery trains' (of ammunition wagons pulled by teams of horses).  They also were more likely to parade with 'side arms' (i.e. bayonets), whereas it was only the Royal Garrison Artillery who were dressed as foot borne soldiers.  The RFA and RHA were both dressed and accoutred as mounted troops and would not have paraded with side arms.

comment.author: 66941036@N05
comment._content: As the men are without long arms (rifles) this is very likely to be a Church Parade with soldiers of the local garrison marching in discrete bodies (i.e. in unit detachments) either to or from church.  This was a regular routine at that time, usually accompanied by the band(s).
